p: The invasive species in this study exhibited higher values of SLA, on average, than did their congeneric naturalized relatives. Evidence suggests that SLA is highly influential in the invasion process (Baruch & Goldstein 1999; Grotkopp et al. 2002; Leishman et al. 2007, 2010). Although multivariate studies show that traits such as growth form, flowering season, height, and native range size are associated with the probability of progressing through the invasion continuum (Gravuer et al. 2008; Hanspach et al. 2008; Milbau & Scott 2008; Bucharova & Van Kleunen 2009), no one has investigated the role of SLA. This omission likely reflects a lack of available comparative data for this trait or the time-consuming nature of its collection in the field.
